comments.text:
Claire is right! How is telling a true story glorifying anything? The 
definition of glorify is "make something appear superior: to cause 
something to seem more pleasant, important, or desirable than is actually 
the case" therefore as this is a true story and Jordan Belfort himself said 
almost everything in the film was the way it happened with few minor non 
important changes. He also said they also actually toned some things down a 
little. Therefore in no way was this film glorified. Leo said he made this 
film to expose the this culture and how greed and excess can destroy 
people. It is a cautionary tale. He made it with noble intentions. 
Obviously most people including myself don't agree with how these 
characters behaved but I think that's the point. If you see the movie in 
the right light you will be able to see how brilliant his performance 
was. Leo is an actor (therefore his character is not who he is) and he 
takes on roles that will challenge him. Not safe roles that will be a 
guaranteed box office hit. If you are uncomfortable watching it that is 
perfectly understandable, a lot of people are easily offended but this film 
was not a porno . It had nudity yes but it was a true story of a man who 
actually lived like that. I think some people are just uncomfortable with 
the truth sometimes.

I'd like to think so because I think he's a brilliant actor, but, sadly, I 
don't think that's entirely true. Think about it, his best chance of 
winning an Oscar was probably last year for the Wolf of Wall Street. Don't 
get me wrong, he's great in that film, but you also have to contemplate the 
fact that people like Matthew Mcconaughey and Chiwetel Ejiofor were 
nominated as well for the Oscar. Mcconaughey was the deserved winner of 
that year; he was exceptional in Dallas Buyers Club, like truly 
outstanding. The same applies to Ejiofor to Twelve Years a Slave. He gave, 
in my opinion, the second best performance of the year. You also have 
Christian Bale with his incredible performance in American Hustle. So, 
really, Dicaprio was up against stiff competition and, in the end, he was 
unlucky to be put up against such great actors. Ultimately, however, he 
didn't deserve to win the Oscar that year.

comments.author: BohemianAsh

comments.text:
Homophobic? Sexist? Money? Greed and violence? Do you realize that just 
because you depict something in a film doesn't mean that you approve of it? 
To the contrary, you might even criticize what you're showing (or do you 
think for example that Schindler's list is a nazi propaganda film?). The 
Wolf of Wall Street is based on the memoirs by Jordan Belfort and the film 
is pretty faithful, so I'm sorry to tell you, but it just happens that 
those guys in the film were greedy, homophobic drug and sex addicts who 
didn't give a shit about their wifes (or anyone for that matter). Actually, 
Jordan Belfort stated that the events in real life were even worse. Anyone 
with a decent moral compass will realize, just like you, that Belfort is a 
despicable human being. Life isn't a Disney film and many people do 
terrible things, deal with it. It's the new film by arguably the greatest 
living filmmaker, very well-made and with great performances and that's all 
you have to say?
What's next? Criticizing a film about Hitler for being antisemitic or a 
film about slavery because it's racist towards black people? I think 
Ellen's able to judge for herself if she thinks the film is sexist and/or 
homophobic and especially, if that's the case, what the film tries to say 
with it. She just happened to have come to a different conclusion than you.
The fact that you "feel horrible" and couldn't stop watching is kind of a 
compliment for the film. The main problem with the film is rather that it 
drags and isn't that engaging because it's hard to care for such awful 
human beings.

comments.text:
Take a look at the years DiCaprio could've won. His best shot at receiving 
an Oscar was probably for Wolf of Wall Street or Django Unchained. The year 
he was nominated for Wolf was the same year that both Matthew Mcconaughey 
for Dallas Buyers Club and Chiwetel Ejiofor for Twelve Years a Slave was 
nominated. Mcconaughey won, rightly so, but second would have easily been 
Ejiofor because he was outstanding; not to mention Christian Bale for his 
stunning performance in American Hustle as well. He was very close to 
winning an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor for Django Unchained and an 
argument could definitely be made for that. However, Christoph Waltz killed 
it in that film and he won the Oscar which was the right decision. DiCaprio 
has simply been unlucky each year as he's put up against phenomenal actors.

INTO HIS MOUTH AS WELL,

AND HE CRASHED INTO
A PLATE GLASS TABLE,

AND WE WERE DOING
THIS CPR SEQUENCE,

AND, YOU KNOW,
THE BIG CHALLENGE THAT DAY--
WE HAD TO DO 70 TAKES

BECAUSE THEY COULDN'T GET
THIS HAM
TO STICK ON MY FACE.
[laughter]
AND THEY HAD TO PUT K-Y JELLY,

AND THERE WAS LITERALLY
A GUY THERE

BEHIND THIS GUY
WITH A PLASTIC SPOON

JUST FLICKING HAM
ON MY FACE ALL DAY LONG

AS I'M DOING
THIS INSANE SEQUENCE,
BUT IT WAS--IT WAS ALMOST--

IT WAS ONE OF THE MOST
SURREAL THINGS I'VE EVER DONE
IN MY ENTIRE CAREER.

title: Leonardo DiCaprio Discusses 'The Wolf of Wall Street'
